title: Man, ‘significant’ number of birds and snakes killed in Methuen house fire, department says
author: Sana Muneer
bullets: A Methuen house fire killed one man and a significant number of birds and snakes Tuesday morning, officials said.
Firefighters took four hours to control the blaze at 38 Atkinson St., which caused catastrophic damage to the home.
The fire's cause is under investigation by Methuen fire and police departments and State Police fire investigators.

title: What readers say Boston Mayor Michelle Wu should prioritize in her next term
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Boston.com readers prioritize housing affordability and public safety as key issues for Mayor Michelle Wu's next term.
Housing affordability and public safety garnered 49% of responses in a Boston.com informal poll with nearly 80 participants.
Readers suggest zoning changes and increased rent assistance for housing, and enhanced measures for community safety.

title: Pay transparency is now law in Massachusetts. What does it mean for you?
author: Pattie Hunt Sinacole
bullets: Massachusetts enacted a pay transparency law effective October 29, requiring employers to disclose pay ranges in job postings.
The law applies to Massachusetts employers with 25 or more employees and covers jobs paid by salary, commission, or hourly rates.
Employers with 100+ employees must submit annual wage reports; violations can lead to penalties after a short grace period.

title: Salem woman who ran ‘creepy creations’ shop to plead guilty in Harvard morgue scandal
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Katrina Maclean to plead guilty to transporting stolen human remains from the Harvard Medical School morgue.
Maclean accused of selling stolen remains at her 'Kat's Creepy Creations' store in Peabody, Massachusetts.
Prosecutors recommend 12 months imprisonment after plea deal; Maclean reserves right to appeal dismissal denial.

title: Tell us: What’s the best New England town for a winter weekend getaway?
author: Kristi Palma
bullets: Boston.com is seeking recommendations for the best New England town for a winter weekend getaway.
Notable destinations include Boston, Nantucket, Woodstock, Bar Harbor, Portsmouth, and Mystic, recognized for winter charm.
Readers are invited to submit suggestions via email for potential feature on Boston.com.

title: Boston ranks among best U.S. cities for Thanksgiving — and tops New England
author: Frances Klemm
bullets: Boston ranked 18th in WalletHub's list of best U.S. cities for Thanksgiving, leading New England entries.
Boston's high ranking driven by its restaurant scene, including many with Yelp ratings of 4.5 stars or higher.
The city scored well for volunteer metrics, reflecting strong community engagement and charitable contributions.

title: Five years after debuting ‘Java with Jimmy,’ host James Hills isn’t slowing down
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: James 'Jimmy' Hills started 'Java with Jimmy' during the COVID-19 pandemic, aiming to address community issues in Boston.
Hills' show features interviews with politicians, community organizers, and local leaders, building a dedicated audience called 'Java Fam'.
Despite not planning to run for office, Hills aspires to expand his platform into a community-centric media outlet.

title: Roman Anthony earns a third place finish for AL Rookie of the Year
author: Aidan Buchanan
bullets: Roman Anthony finished third in the AL Rookie of the Year vote, behind Nick Kurtz and Jacob Wilson.
Anthony hit .292 with eight home runs and 32 RBIs in 71 games for the Boston Red Sox.
Despite finishing third, Anthony signed an eight-year, $130 million contract extension with the Red Sox in August.

title: Federal judge orders release of Fitchburg woman detained by ICE in viral video
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Federal judge orders release of Juliana Milena Ojeda Montoya after viral ICE arrest in Fitchburg.
Judge Neumann cites due process violations, sets briefs deadline on Laken Riley Act applicability for Nov. 14.
Ojeda Montoya arrested for alleged assault, DHS claims husband's medical episode was faked during arrest.

title: How Mass. lawmakers are reacting to the deal that could end the government shutdown
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Massachusetts lawmakers criticize Senate's funding bill, citing lack of healthcare subsidy extension vital for 330,000 state residents.
Rep. Seth Moulton calls for new leadership, opposing Senate deal; targets Sen. Chuck Schumer as ineffective on healthcare issue.
Massachusetts delegation, including Reps. Ayanna Pressley and Katherine Clark, denounce bill for failing to address healthcare and middle-class costs.
